Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Hemiarthroplasty and Internal Fixation for Displaced Femoral Neck Fractures

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 222 patients with FNF were randomised

Participants.evidence: 222 patients with FNF were randomised to receive either internal fixation with two parallel screws or bipolar hemiarthroplasty. The study was conducted in a hospital setting.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either internal fixation with two parallel screws or bipolar hemiarthroplasty

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of hemiarthroplasty versus internal fixation for displaced femoral neck fractures (FNF) in patients over 60 years.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was hip function, measured by the Harris hip score, at a minimum follow-up of 5 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to the treatment groups.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 110 patients were randomised to hemiarthroplasty and 112 to internal fixation.

Number_Analysed.evidence: At a mean follow-up of 5.9 years, 68 of the 70 surviving patients were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean Harris hip score was 66 in the internal fixation group and 67 in the hemiarthroplasty group (p = 0.96).

Harms.evidence: Reoperation was more frequent in the internal fixation group.
